abstract: Speaking words that are bound to disappoint a few investment bankers, Jeffrey Immelt, the chief executive of General Electric, said the giant conglomerate is likely to avoid big deals for the time being. Interviewed by The Financial Times after the announcement that a Saudi Arabian company would buy G.E.’s plastics business for about $11.6 billion, Mr. Immelt said, “I like the company in the current position. We will remain tough-minded about opportunities, but the sale of the plastics business is consistent with our strategy.” Instead, he indicated that the company will look to return excess cash to shareholders and expand its current lines of business.
lead_paragraph: Speaking words that are bound to disappoint a few investment bankers, Jeffrey Immelt, the chief executive of General Electric, said the giant conglomerate is likely to avoid big deals for the time being. Interviewed by The Financial Times after the announcement that a Saudi Arabian company would buy G.E.’s plastics business for about $11.6 billion, Mr. Immelt said, “I like the company in the current position. We will remain tough-minded about opportunities, but the sale of the plastics business is consistent with our strategy.” Instead, he indicated that the company will look to return excess cash to shareholders and expand its current lines of business.

headline.main: Is Jeff Immelt Done With Deal Making?
